00:21:35.140 --> 00:21:41.925
With it selected I just say
hello Ronnie and that's it.

395
00:21:41.925 --> 00:21:45.050
Now once it's text you
could select the text.

396
00:21:45.050 --> 00:21:47.860
You could come over to your home tab.

397
00:21:47.860 --> 00:21:49.470
You could make it bigger.

398
00:21:49.470 --> 00:21:52.480
You could make it a different font,

399
00:21:52.480 --> 00:21:56.810
I'll throw that curls into you got
it throw the curls in there, Ronnie.

400
00:21:56.810 --> 00:21:59.000
I can make it a different color.

401
00:21:59.000 --> 00:22:00.650
I can make it pink.

402
00:22:00.650 --> 00:22:01.210
>> Of course.

403
00:22:01.210 --> 00:22:02.250
>> Of course, Ronnie.

404
00:22:02.250 --> 00:22:02.990
>> Yes.

405
00:22:02.990 --> 00:22:04.950
>> And I can take it and
change it however I want.

406
00:22:04.950 --> 00:22:05.990
It's really hard to see.

407
00:22:05.990 --> 00:22:07.628
So maybe I'll make it white.

408
00:22:07.628 --> 00:22:08.830
How about that?

409
00:22:08.830 --> 00:22:10.460
In a blue shape.

410
00:22:10.460 --> 00:22:11.908
>> Don't make color for curls empty.

411
00:22:11.908 --> 00:22:14.390
[LAUGH]
>> So I can go ahead and

412
00:22:14.390 --> 00:22:16.370
change all of those
different things about it.

413
00:22:17.550 --> 00:22:19.580
It's like in the shape, just a shape,

414
00:22:19.580 --> 00:22:22.260
I clicked off it,
then select the shape again.

415
00:22:22.260 --> 00:22:25.910
Come back here to format,
you also have a whole section in here of

416
00:22:25.910 --> 00:22:31.290
how your text is going to work within
this shape I have some WordArt styles.

417
00:22:31.290 --> 00:22:35.940
Maybe I wanna make it with a little drop
shadow, or that's kinda hard to see.

418
00:22:35.940 --> 00:22:38.850
But we can see all the different
ways that I might want to

419
00:22:38.850 --> 00:22:42.610
format my text with a WordArt style.

420
00:22:42.610 --> 00:22:44.270
I also have the direction.

421
00:22:44.270 --> 00:22:46.270
Do I want it up and down?

422
00:22:46.270 --> 00:22:47.930
Do I want it rotated?

423
00:22:47.930 --> 00:22:48.903
Or I want it horizontal.

424
00:22:48.903 --> 00:22:53.826
You also have just the straight fill
of the text versus the outline versus

425
00:22:53.826 --> 00:22:58.506
all of those different effects that
you can do on the text just like you

426
00:22:58.506 --> 00:23:00.052
could with the shape.

427
00:23:00.052 --> 00:23:03.511
You also have the angle or

428
00:23:03.511 --> 00:23:09.450
the vertical justification of your text.

429
00:23:09.450 --> 00:23:11.220
Where do you want it to align?

430
00:23:11.220 --> 00:23:12.720
Because in the middle, that screen,

431
00:23:12.720 --> 00:23:15.590
maybe you want to put it
towards the top or the bottom.

432
00:23:15.590 --> 00:23:20.170
And some shapes, like a heart,
there might not be so

433
00:23:20.170 --> 00:23:22.050
much room for a top and a bottom.

434
00:23:22.050 --> 00:23:23.400
It might not move so much.

435
00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:28.248
But in a square, that's somewhere where
you can really see the different things

436
00:23:28.248 --> 00:23:31.320
and the different places
where this text could go.

437
00:23:31.320 --> 00:23:35.135
And then of course you always have more
text option you see in this format shape

438
00:23:35.135 --> 00:23:37.790
dialog box, this is not a box,
this is a tough paint.

439
00:23:37.790 --> 00:23:41.380
We're doing the shape options
versus the text options,

440
00:23:41.380 --> 00:23:45.490
this was a new thing that we didn't
see in the heart because well,

441
00:23:45.490 --> 00:23:49.253
we didn't have any text added
into that particular shape.

442
00:23:49.253 --> 00:23:52.477
So we have all these different
things that we can go for.

443
00:23:52.477 --> 00:23:57.140
Go really crazy with that
particular level of formatting.

444
00:23:58.510 --> 00:24:02.413
So those are the basics of
formatting your shapes.

445
00:24:02.413 --> 00:24:06.709
I'm gonna scroll down a little bit more
because I wanted to show you a few other

446
00:24:06.709 --> 00:24:09.910
shapes, and what they can do for
us that are kind of fun.

447
00:24:09.910 --> 00:24:12.190
Ronnie, I know you like to have fun.

448
00:24:12.190 --> 00:24:12.810
>> I do.

449
00:24:12.810 --> 00:24:13.680
>> You do?
[LAUGH]

450
00:24:13.680 --> 00:24:14.290
>> Yes, I do.

451
00:24:14.290 --> 00:24:15.187
>> Yes you do.

452
00:24:15.187 --> 00:24:18.174
How about we make a nice sun?

453
00:24:18.174 --> 00:24:19.087
>> Nice.

454
00:24:19.087 --> 00:24:21.630
>> Big old sun,
the sun's actually out today.

455
00:24:21.630 --> 00:24:25.080
It's the first time in quite
some time here in rainy Florida.

456
00:24:25.080 --> 00:24:29.115
So, we click, hold, and
drag, make the sun.

457
00:24:29.115 --> 00:24:31.090
And let's make one more.

458
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:35.140
I'm going to make this particular one,
this arrow.

459
00:24:36.240 --> 00:24:37.440
Select it, drag it.

460
00:24:38.510 --> 00:24:41.110
On some of your shapes, like the sun or

461
00:24:41.110 --> 00:24:45.680
the arch,
you've got these cool little yellow dots.

462
00:24:45.680 --> 00:24:49.330
Now, they used to be diamonds, they
used to call them yellow diamonds, but

463
00:24:49.330 --> 00:24:52.840
they're modifiers of a shape.

464
00:24:52.840 --> 00:24:56.095
If I click and hold on them,
and I drag in.

465
00:24:56.095 --> 00:25:00.705
Look at that,
I can make the rays of the sun thinner and

466
00:25:00.705 --> 00:25:02.435
longer-
>> Right.

467
00:25:02.435 --> 00:25:03.790
>> On this arrow.

468
00:25:03.790 --> 00:25:07.210
Let me kind of zoom in a little bit,
so you can see a little bit more.

469
00:25:07.210 --> 00:25:10.390
It might not be really pronounced
on the screen right now,

470
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:12.250
but there is one right here.

471
00:25:12.250 --> 00:25:16.118
And the other thing to
notice is here versus here.

472
00:25:16.118 --> 00:25:19.740
You see how the arrowhead is just
like an arrowhead with no tail.

473
00:25:19.740 --> 00:25:22.620
That's where I can start controlling,
well, look at all of that.

474
00:25:22.620 --> 00:25:29.260
I can make the curve of the arrow
either be pointy or more curvy.

475
00:25:29.260 --> 00:25:32.267
I have this one down here,
let's see what it does.

476
00:25:32.267 --> 00:25:36.700
Okay, it makes the thickness of the stem,
we'll call it, of the arrow.

477
00:25:36.700 --> 00:25:38.030
So I can make that there.

478
00:25:39.120 --> 00:25:41.510
I don't know what each one of these
diamonds, sorry, they're not diamonds,

479
00:25:41.510 --> 00:25:42.300
they're circles, do.

480
00:25:42.300 --> 00:25:43.923
You just click on them and drag them.

481
00:25:43.923 --> 00:25:48.310
So that's gonna,
that makes the head a little larger.

482
00:25:48.310 --> 00:25:52.020
And then this one, okay,
it makes it longer,

483
00:25:52.020 --> 00:25:55.070
we'll call it,
even though we're kinda turned this way.

484
00:25:55.070 --> 00:25:56.010
>> Wider or longer.

485
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:57.211
>> Wider and longer, there we go.

486
00:25:57.211 --> 00:26:01.959
So I could go ahead and modify my arrow
shape to be whatever I want because I have

487
00:26:01.959 --> 00:26:05.860
all these different modifiers along it,
not all of shapes do.

488
00:26:05.860 --> 00:26:08.810
We did not see that on the circle,
we didn't see it on the square,

489
00:26:08.810 --> 00:26:13.720
but the sun, like the smiley face,
you can make it frown.

490
00:26:13.720 --> 00:26:18.412
We can do, like the moon, you can make the
arch of the moon to where it's like just

491
00:26:18.412 --> 00:26:20.413
a little sliver, or a wider moon.

492
00:26:20.413 --> 00:26:22.962
So we have those different options there.

493
00:26:22.962 --> 00:26:27.592
Then the last one I wanted to show
you in this episode was how you

494
00:26:27.592 --> 00:26:29.831
could edit points on a shape.

495
00:26:29.831 --> 00:26:33.917
Let's take the sun here,
I'll make it a little thicker.

496
00:26:33.917 --> 00:26:39.295
So have this, but I wanna just have
the top ray of the sun be longer,

497
00:26:39.295 --> 00:26:42.960
and maybe the two sides
to be that way as well.

498
00:26:44.120 --> 00:26:48.795
You have a button on the Format
tab [LAUGH] to where you

499
00:26:48.795 --> 00:26:52.291
can edit the points or edit the shape.

500
00:26:52.291 --> 00:26:56.303
When you edit the shape,
it's going into that point level of, well,

501
00:26:56.303 --> 00:26:59.440
that's changing the shape,
we don't wanna do that.

502
00:26:59.440 --> 00:27:00.992
But that's a quick way if
you wanted to make this.

503
00:27:00.992 --> 00:27:03.899
Cuz if you had it all formatted,
maybe you had it pink, and rotated, and

504
00:27:03.899 --> 00:27:06.374
you wanted to not be a square,
you wanted it to be a circle now,

505
00:27:06.374 --> 00:27:08.340
that's where you go to change shape.

506
00:27:08.340 --> 00:27:10.370
But the edit points is where
I was wanting to get into.

507
00:27:10.370 --> 00:27:12.400
And this is on that, see, to me,

508
00:27:12.400 --> 00:27:15.262
this is where I'm at home
of editing vector graphics.

509
00:27:15.262 --> 00:27:19.090
I wanna get to the point
level to move things around.

510
00:27:19.090 --> 00:27:24.520
I can move a single point different
than the whole shape or the whole path.

511
00:27:25.540 --> 00:27:30.000
So, if I hover over it, and you get this
kind of square with four little arrows on

512
00:27:30.000 --> 00:27:32.076
it, and I click on this, and I drag.

513
00:27:32.076 --> 00:27:38.460
Do you see how I can pull that one
point up more than the other points?

514
00:27:38.460 --> 00:27:44.240
So maybe I can kinda pull this one out,
pull this one out, and pull this one out.

515
00:27:44.240 --> 00:27:50.010
So I'm modifying the shape
by getting into the points.

516
00:27:50.010 --> 00:27:50.738
That's kinda fun.

517
00:27:50.738 --> 00:27:55.344
But if, again, on shapes that have curves,

518
00:27:55.344 --> 00:28:00.557
this is where you're gonna
kinda get a crush course

519
00:28:00.557 --> 00:28:05.670
into how to edit bezier handles,
bezier points.

520
00:28:05.670 --> 00:28:09.550
The whole thing I was telling
you about with vector graphics,

521
00:28:09.550 --> 00:28:14.712
the whole Idea was something from a French
Mathematician named somebody Bezier.

522
00:28:14.712 --> 00:28:17.836
[LAUGH] I can't remember his first name,
and

523
00:28:17.836 --> 00:28:21.475
he kind of coined this whole idea,
and went for it.

524
00:28:21.475 --> 00:28:25.415
It's all a bunch of math, and
curves, and points, and stuff.

525
00:28:25.415 --> 00:28:28.114
[LAUGH] Well,
I'm gonna come back into edit points.

526
00:28:28.114 --> 00:28:31.473
Cuz if I click on this point,
and I drag it out, you see these,

527
00:28:31.473 --> 00:28:33.970
they're almost like, I call them seesaws.

528
00:28:33.970 --> 00:28:37.080
And if I take this end, and I seesaw it,

529
00:28:37.080 --> 00:28:40.740
see how the other part is
going to seesaw as well.

530
00:28:40.740 --> 00:28:45.640
So you can move the point itself,
you could grab the seesaw,

531
00:28:45.640 --> 00:28:49.050
and then you can also pull it out more.

532
00:28:49.050 --> 00:28:53.110
And that's where, remember I was telling
you with vector graphics how they come in

533
00:28:53.110 --> 00:28:53.980
from one direction.

534
00:28:55.060 --> 00:28:58.200
They travel through a point one way and
they come in to another point.

535
00:28:58.200 --> 00:29:04.420
That's where, if you look at this,
it's coming through the point this way,

536
00:29:04.420 --> 00:29:07.940
and then traveling into the point,
but it comes out from, oops,

537
00:29:07.940 --> 00:29:12.520
I just clicked one too many, from here.

538
00:29:12.520 --> 00:29:17.580
So that's where it kinda gets
that arch of traveling in and

539
00:29:17.580 --> 00:29:22.910
out of these points, and how you
change the angle of how it comes in.

540
00:29:22.910 --> 00:29:27.491
That's where you get your S curves,
or your bends, any type of curves.

541
00:29:27.491 --> 00:29:30.616
It doesn't have to be an S curve,
it could be a whatever type of curve.

542
00:29:30.616 --> 00:29:36.097
But that's what you will experience when
you're editing points on shapes that

543
00:29:36.097 --> 00:29:42.510
have curves rather than straight points
like a rectangle or the rays of the sun.

544
00:29:42.510 --> 00:29:45.390
That gives you a little
bit more options for

545
00:29:45.390 --> 00:29:48.120
what you can do to make
your own custom shapes.

546
00:29:48.120 --> 00:29:51.890
You can make some blobs,
like I just made on the screen.

547
00:29:51.890 --> 00:29:56.249
And so, that's how we can get the shapes
in, that's how we can format them,

548
00:29:56.249 --> 00:30:00.157
add text, get into the format shape
task pane, and edit the points.

549
00:30:00.157 --> 00:30:05.740
So those were my main points that I wanted
to make for you guys here in this episode.

550
00:30:05.740 --> 00:30:09.730
And we'll have another episode where
we're gonna talk about multiple shapes,

551
00:30:09.730 --> 00:30:12.760
where we'll get into working
with a couple of these.

552
00:30:12.760 --> 00:30:15.740
We'll talk about groups and
some different things like that.

553
00:30:15.740 --> 00:30:17.380
So, stick around.

554
00:30:17.380 --> 00:30:20.135
>> All right Vonne, well,
thank you again for helping us out.

555
00:30:20.135 --> 00:30:23.757
And that last one on editing those
points that was really neat.

556
00:30:23.757 --> 00:30:26.528
I didn't know that you could
take just a basic shape, and

557
00:30:26.528 --> 00:30:29.170
kind of create the shape
that you want instead.

558
00:30:29.170 --> 00:30:30.900
But there's a lot more to come, of course.

559
00:30:30.900 --> 00:30:33.200
But those are for other episodes as well.

560
00:30:33.200 --> 00:30:37.418
So, signing off for Office Pro TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

561
00:30:37.418 --> 00:30:38.495
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

562
00:30:38.495 --> 00:30:44.170
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Word 2016 Advanced shows.

563
00:30:44.170 --> 00:30:50.005
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne demonstrate working with multiple shapes and icons. With shapes, Vonne shows how to duplicate, arrange stacking order, align, group and ungroup, and use the selection pane. She also covers how to insert icons, which is only available with an Office 365 subscription.
episodes.title: Multiple Shapes and Icons
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.988
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.988 --> 00:00:09.736
Welcome to another great episode
right here on OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.736 --> 00:00:14.180
You're watching the Microsoft Word
2016 advanced show.

4
00:00:14.180 --> 00:00:16.100
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

5
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:21.330
today we'll be diving into what
multiple shapes and icons.

6
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:25.280
So we've already talked about individual
shapes, and how we can manipulate them.

7
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:26.580
And now we're moving beyond that and

8
00:00:26.580 --> 00:00:29.600
actually learning how to
juggle with shades as well.

9
00:00:29.600 --> 00:00:30.630
So that brings us then on,

10
00:00:30.630 --> 00:00:33.985
of course then, our master juggler
herself, Miss Vonne Smith.

11
00:00:33.985 --> 00:00:35.135
Vonne, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:35.135 --> 00:00:37.290
>> [LAUGH] Yes, I like master juggler.

13
00:00:37.290 --> 00:00:38.050
>> There you go.

14
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:41.310
>> Because we are gonna be
juggling multiple shades.

15
00:00:41.310 --> 00:00:45.610
And then we're gonna throw icons in there
which are different in shapes but they're

16
00:00:45.610 --> 00:00:49.790
kinda just like shapes but my favorite
saying they're the same but different.

17
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:54.652
>> Yes, so they're like the chainsaw
of juggling in shapes, aren't they?

18
00:00:54.652 --> 00:00:56.301
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah they're just,

19
00:00:56.301 --> 00:00:58.217
they're shapes to the next level.

20
00:00:58.217 --> 00:00:59.722
They're shapes 2.0.

21
00:00:59.722 --> 00:01:00.433
How about that?

22
00:01:00.433 --> 00:01:02.510
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah I guess they're like juggling

23
00:01:02.510 --> 00:01:05.640
chain saws that's kinda the last
thing that you really want to juggle.

24
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:06.378
>> Yeah, probably.

25
00:01:06.378 --> 00:01:10.533
[LAUGH] We're gonna get in to how
I can take a couple shapes and

26
00:01:10.533 --> 00:01:11.955
make one big shape.

27
00:01:11.955 --> 00:01:14.670
We're going to talk about groups and
un-grouping and

28
00:01:14.670 --> 00:01:16.640
when you might want to do that.

29
00:01:16.640 --> 00:01:18.580
We'll also talk about,

30
00:01:18.580 --> 00:01:21.290
if we're going to have multiple shapes,
how do I select them?

31
00:01:21.290 --> 00:01:25.480
How do I kind of manipulate multiple
shapes to create something.

32
00:01:25.480 --> 00:01:30.325
I think well, I'm already thinking about,
maybe we'll put like a heart inside

33
00:01:30.325 --> 00:01:33.262
the sun, and
put a little cloud over to the side.

34
00:01:33.262 --> 00:01:34.164
I don't know.

35
00:01:34.164 --> 00:01:36.850
Ronnie we're just gonna have fun and
just build it.

36
00:01:36.850 --> 00:01:38.065
So let's just go.

37
00:01:38.065 --> 00:01:40.030
[LAUGH]
>> That sounds like a great idea Vonne.

38
00:01:40.030 --> 00:01:44.030
So when we start dealing
with multiple shapes, what

39
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:47.690
are the elements we've really got to think
about when we start putting it together?

40
00:01:47.690 --> 00:01:50.000
A lot of it's gonna be of course
our own personal preference, but

41
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:51.070
what else do we need to know?

42
00:01:51.070 --> 00:01:52.684
>> We need to know about stacking order.

43
00:01:52.684 --> 00:01:55.510
Stacking order and how to select them.

44
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:56.920
So why don't I show you?

45
00:01:56.920 --> 00:02:00.221
Let's jump on down into
our blank document.

46
00:02:00.221 --> 00:02:02.921
And I do have our other
document down here,

47
00:02:02.921 --> 00:02:08.380
the ad graphics that's been closed and
not saved, so we have it restart it again.

48
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:12.891
Because if I'm gonna make like
a more complex type of object,

49
00:02:12.891 --> 00:02:16.467
it might be good to do it
in a blank document here.

50
00:02:16.467 --> 00:02:17.809
It's almost like we're
going to the drawing board.

51
00:02:17.809 --> 00:02:19.040
We're gonna go ahead and create it.

52
00:02:19.040 --> 00:02:20.187
It's like arts and crafts.

53
00:02:20.187 --> 00:02:25.100
We're gonna glue it all together and
then put it over somewhere else.

54
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:27.260
That's kind of what I would suggest doing.

55
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:32.460
Build it up, group it, get to where you
like it, move it on over, just copy and

56
00:02:32.460 --> 00:02:36.650
paste it into your Word document and
do all of the different word wraps and

57
00:02:36.650 --> 00:02:39.420
positionings and
all those different things we've talked

58
00:02:39.420 --> 00:02:44.360
about in the shapes adding format episode.

59
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:45.731

289
00:14:31.280 --> 00:14:34.330
realize, I wanted to have
the heart to be a different color.

290
00:14:34.330 --> 00:14:36.440
Well, right now, this is one piece.

291
00:14:36.440 --> 00:14:43.030
If I size it down, it's all gonna
take this one entity as a group.

292
00:14:43.030 --> 00:14:44.605
So here you can get into isolation mode.

293
00:14:44.605 --> 00:14:46.430
There's actually two options you could do.

294
00:14:46.430 --> 00:14:50.200
You could ungroup it cuz things that
can be grouped can be ungrouped.

295
00:14:50.200 --> 00:14:52.720
You could ungroup it, click off of it.

296
00:14:52.720 --> 00:14:53.252
Click on one item,

297
00:14:53.252 --> 00:14:57.780
change it, click off of it,
select them all again and then group it.

298
00:15:00.680 --> 00:15:03.360
That was really a lot of
times some of the only ways

299
00:15:03.360 --> 00:15:05.920
you could do this before some of these
products have advanced in this way.

300
00:15:05.920 --> 00:15:08.230
And so we get into isolation mode.

301
00:15:08.230 --> 00:15:09.560
I'm still in the group.

302
00:15:09.560 --> 00:15:13.390
But if I and I selected it,
single click on the heart, you see,

303
00:15:13.390 --> 00:15:14.540
now I have a box in box.

304
00:15:14.540 --> 00:15:16.590
It's almost like this,
like a picture in picture.

305
00:15:16.590 --> 00:15:19.230
I have a box that is
selected within the group.

306
00:15:19.230 --> 00:15:22.990
And if I change this fill here to,
we'll make it blue,

307
00:15:22.990 --> 00:15:25.460
now I've just changed the heart.

308
00:15:25.460 --> 00:15:29.240
I'm gonna click off,
single-click on the whole group.

309
00:15:29.240 --> 00:15:34.240
If I came up to the fill shape here,
see I’m changing all of them because it’s

310
00:15:34.240 --> 00:15:38.730
selecting all of the grouped elements
in here and that’s not what I want.

311
00:15:38.730 --> 00:15:42.980
So watch for
your isolation mode to get into

312
00:15:42.980 --> 00:15:48.710
one specific item within a group,
without ever having to ungroup it.

313
00:15:48.710 --> 00:15:51.993
But if you did need to ungroup it,
say you got this from somebody else and

314
00:15:51.993 --> 00:15:54.181
like, I really like that
star out of there and

315
00:15:54.181 --> 00:15:56.512
you didn’t know that you
can create it yourself.

316
00:15:56.512 --> 00:15:59.253
If you right click,
you can go to group and ungroup or

317
00:15:59.253 --> 00:16:03.009
you can go to that other button up here
on the ribbon to do the same thing.

318
00:16:03.009 --> 00:16:04.121
And then I ungroup.

319
00:16:04.121 --> 00:16:08.210
It's now the individual
pieces by themselves again.

320
00:16:08.210 --> 00:16:12.150
So all these different ways to know if
it's a group by using that selection pane,

321
00:16:12.150 --> 00:16:14.050
turning on and off things.

322
00:16:14.050 --> 00:16:20.160
Making sure you know how to
isolate the pieces of a group.

323
00:16:20.160 --> 00:16:23.560
I just did an undo,
I just did a Ctrl+Z to get this one shape.

324
00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:28.230
And this is where you would take this,
copy it, I just did a Ctrl+C,

325
00:16:28.230 --> 00:16:31.020
come over to your other page,
you paste it.

326
00:16:31.020 --> 00:16:34.180
That is not going to,
let's try that again.

327
00:16:34.180 --> 00:16:36.730
Select this, oops, hold on.

328
00:16:36.730 --> 00:16:37.980
See right there?

329
00:16:37.980 --> 00:16:41.175
I am selecting and
isolating the sun from the group.

330
00:16:41.175 --> 00:16:42.421
>> Okay.
>> Careful.

331
00:16:42.421 --> 00:16:44.674
That's why I always tell people,
click off.

332
00:16:44.674 --> 00:16:47.210
Just go and click off over there.

333
00:16:47.210 --> 00:16:49.112
To deselect start over,

334
00:16:49.112 --> 00:16:54.125
single click to get just the whole group,
let's click the copy.

335
00:16:54.125 --> 00:16:59.769
>> [LAUGH]
>> Come over to our graphics, paste there.

336
00:16:59.769 --> 00:17:04.810
I think I just didn't hit the right
key as to make the Ctrl+C work.

337
00:17:04.810 --> 00:17:08.308
And I can then use my
Text wrap with my Tight,

338
00:17:08.308 --> 00:17:13.620
move it around here,
maybe put it right in the middle for fun.

339
00:17:13.620 --> 00:17:20.638
So, I created my shape off to the side
in a sense in another Word file.

340
00:17:20.638 --> 00:17:24.930
Brought it into my document, moved it
around, applied the wrap the way I would

341
00:17:24.930 --> 00:17:27.730
like it to be and
I think that's kinda the easiest way.

342
00:17:27.730 --> 00:17:32.120
Design, copy, and bring it on in.

343
00:17:32.120 --> 00:17:32.770
>> Icons.

344
00:17:32.770 --> 00:17:34.899
>> Icons, shapes 2.0.

345
00:17:34.899 --> 00:17:37.325
They're like emojis.

346
00:17:37.325 --> 00:17:38.347
>> Emojis!

347
00:17:38.347 --> 00:17:40.653
>> Right?
Cute little characters we can do on

348
00:17:40.653 --> 00:17:41.308
our phone.

349
00:17:41.308 --> 00:17:45.910
Thumbs up, or smiley face, or
thumbs down, you know, all those things.

350
00:17:45.910 --> 00:17:51.860
They're not as elaborate as that,
but they are icons.

351
00:17:51.860 --> 00:17:56.460
Icons are only available for
subscription-based Word, so

352
00:17:56.460 --> 00:18:00.310
if you had a subscription to Office 365,
then you will get icons.

353
00:18:00.310 --> 00:18:03.880
If you have a standalone volume,
then you're not going to have this.

354
00:18:03.880 --> 00:18:05.645
It might, well, no because.

355
00:18:05.645 --> 00:18:10.583
[LAUGH] As soon as I say that, I'm like,
well it might be, but I remember even

356
00:18:10.583 --> 00:18:16.360
since I've been filming these Office
episodes, this was part of a update.

357
00:18:16.360 --> 00:18:17.390
It was there one time.

358
00:18:17.390 --> 00:18:19.321
I'm like well look at there,
they added icons.

359
00:18:19.321 --> 00:18:21.894
And that is a really nice
thing about the subscription,

360
00:18:21.894 --> 00:18:24.480
is that you're always getting
these little elements.

361
00:18:24.480 --> 00:18:26.895
And it just kind of pops up and
I'm like, look at that.

362
00:18:26.895 --> 00:18:30.680
And then I go and find in the list
of what they have updated,

363
00:18:30.680 --> 00:18:33.080
I see that they've done icons.

364
00:18:33.080 --> 00:18:37.260
I don't remember what build it was,
but it was a couple of them ago.

365
00:18:37.260 --> 00:18:40.540
On the insert tab, I have Icons.

366
00:18:40.540 --> 00:18:44.010
I'm also aware that now
I'm in my add graphics, so

367
00:18:44.010 --> 00:18:46.140
I've got to make sure my
cursor's in the right place.

368
00:18:46.140 --> 00:18:48.300
Just like if I was inserting an image.

369
00:18:48.300 --> 00:18:50.300
Go out to Icons, it's going out online.

370
00:18:50.300 --> 00:18:52.760
So you do also have to be
connected to the Internet here.

371
00:18:52.760 --> 00:18:55.180
There we go,
say I wanted to put in a little baby.

372
00:18:55.180 --> 00:18:57.930
Or I want to put in a printer.

373
00:18:57.930 --> 00:18:59.055
Is that a printer, Ronnie?

374
00:18:59.055 --> 00:19:00.310
>> It looks like a printer.

375
00:19:00.310 --> 00:19:01.817
>> [LAUGH] Looks like a printer to me.

376
00:19:01.817 --> 00:19:02.317
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

377
00:19:02.317 --> 00:19:03.173
>> Kinda old school.

378
00:19:03.173 --> 00:19:04.995
Look at the three inch floppy disc.

379
00:19:04.995 --> 00:19:05.797
>> Nice.
>> [LAUGH] So

380
00:19:05.797 --> 00:19:09.223
you have the different
categories over here.

381
00:19:09.223 --> 00:19:11.174
And if you just keep on scrolling,

382
00:19:11.174 --> 00:19:14.555
you'll be able to see the different
ones that you might do.

383
00:19:14.555 --> 00:19:17.662
And this would be things for
more business like.

384
00:19:17.662 --> 00:19:20.460
You wanna add something,
a little piece of flair, but

385
00:19:20.460 --> 00:19:25.040
you don't want to maybe draw hearts and
stars, like we were doing.

386
00:19:25.040 --> 00:19:28.800
So, let's scroll on down,
I know it's in here.

387
00:19:28.800 --> 00:19:30.410
>> No, there's not a bunny.

388
00:19:30.410 --> 00:19:31.870
>> There is, right there.

389
00:19:31.870 --> 00:19:32.860
>> There it is, fair enough.

390
00:19:34.254 --> 00:19:35.457
>> You know I found that one, Ronnie.

391
00:19:35.457 --> 00:19:36.389
>> And a fish bowl.

392
00:19:36.389 --> 00:19:39.066
>> There is a fish bowl,
but we're going with bunny.

393
00:19:39.066 --> 00:19:39.639
>> Of course.

394
00:19:39.639 --> 00:19:44.218
>> So, I go and click the bunny and
you click insert and it puts this in.

395
00:19:44.218 --> 00:19:44.881
>> A bunny.

396
00:19:44.881 --> 00:19:46.553
>> It does act like a graphic or

397
00:19:46.553 --> 00:19:50.500
a photograph in the sense that it
will be in-line with the text.

398
00:19:50.500 --> 00:19:54.976
You still have all the same options
that you did before with your wrap and

399
00:19:54.976 --> 00:19:56.410
so on and so forth.

400
00:19:56.410 --> 00:20:02.070
You can make it bigger by clicking
the corner, holding the shift key,

401
00:20:02.070 --> 00:20:07.250
making sure it's proportionate,
changing the fill, it's gotta be pink.

402
00:20:07.250 --> 00:20:09.350
And changing the outline.

403
00:20:09.350 --> 00:20:13.493
And notice that here,
this is where any type of cutout,

404
00:20:13.493 --> 00:20:16.235
the outline goes all the way in that.

405
00:20:16.235 --> 00:20:19.384
And you can still put on your shadows and
your bevels and

406
00:20:19.384 --> 00:20:21.910
all the same options that you can do.

407
00:20:21.910 --> 00:20:24.020
That bevel looks a little strange,
now doesn't it?

408
00:20:24.020 --> 00:20:24.845
Okay, we'll undo that.

409
00:20:24.845 --> 00:20:27.200
[LAUGH] And I will just keep it like this.

410
00:20:28.810 --> 00:20:31.080
That's, I mean it's all the same stuff.

411
00:20:31.080 --> 00:20:35.660
It's just more options that you have for
cool little shapes,

412
00:20:35.660 --> 00:20:38.136
shapes 2.0, that are icons.

413
00:20:38.136 --> 00:20:40.869
And you can still group
it with other items.

414
00:20:40.869 --> 00:20:44.745
The other thing with a group
is we're just using shapes,

415
00:20:44.745 --> 00:20:49.900
if I wanted to insert a picture,
I'm almost scared cuz it's gonna crash.

416
00:20:49.900 --> 00:20:52.563
Sorry, I've been having a little issue for
some reason.

417
00:20:52.563 --> 00:20:57.140
I don't know what it is,
if I insert a picture, it crashes Word.

418
00:20:58.590 --> 00:21:02.277
There was just a recent update, and I
think it was just kind of getting a little

419
00:21:02.277 --> 00:21:04.395
wonky, and sometimes when you do updates.

420
00:21:04.395 --> 00:21:05.974
>> You had to do it.

421
00:21:05.974 --> 00:21:06.613
>> Right, Ronnie?

422
00:21:06.613 --> 00:21:08.892
>> Yeah.
>> Then they have to issue a patch for it,

423
00:21:08.892 --> 00:21:11.431
and then everything will,
it will be fixed, okay?

424
00:21:11.431 --> 00:21:12.394
>> Right.

425
00:21:12.394 --> 00:21:13.753
>> It's not doing the same
thing in PowerPoint.

426
00:21:13.753 --> 00:21:15.436
We figured that out today.

427
00:21:15.436 --> 00:21:17.888
We've been troubleshooting all day long.

428
00:21:17.888 --> 00:21:21.370
I just wanted to let you know,
that if you had a photograph in your file,

429
00:21:21.370 --> 00:21:25.890
and you want to put a shape on top,
like a little star off to the side,

430
00:21:25.890 --> 00:21:29.530
you can group shapes with images.

431
00:21:29.530 --> 00:21:32.020
It doesn't have to be shapes with shapes.

432
00:21:32.020 --> 00:21:35.310
They can all kind of work together
cuz they're all graphical elements.

433
00:21:35.310 --> 00:21:39.526
If you wanted to put a cute little icon
somewhere in the bottom right-hand corner

434
00:21:39.526 --> 00:21:43.443
of your picture, cuz you want to put
almost like a stamp on it or something.

435
00:21:43.443 --> 00:21:45.405
I mean you can do that group it and

436
00:21:45.405 --> 00:21:49.790
move it around the way you're doing
with any of these different items.

437
00:21:49.790 --> 00:21:51.480
So just throwing that out there.

438
00:21:51.480 --> 00:21:53.420
Don't want you to think it's separate.

439
00:21:53.420 --> 00:21:59.460
So icons, shapes, all the different things
we can do with our vector-like images or

440
00:21:59.460 --> 00:22:03.750
vector-like graphics,
we'll call them, in Word.

441
00:22:03.750 --> 00:22:07.130
And so you can have some fun and
gussy up your document.

442
00:22:07.130 --> 00:22:09.950
>> All right, Vonne, that's a great place
for us to actually think about some of

443
00:22:09.950 --> 00:22:12.380
the different things that we
can do with those shapes.

444
00:22:12.380 --> 00:22:13.390
Stacking those shapes,

445
00:22:13.390 --> 00:22:16.990
making sure that they appear in the proper
order in the way we want them to.

446
00:22:16.990 --> 00:22:17.990
It really does help,

447
00:22:17.990 --> 00:22:23.220
especially when we start working with
multiple shapes in those documents.

448
00:22:23.220 --> 00:22:26.800
They're gonna get updated by Microsoft,
so you'll not see just a limited bit of

449
00:22:26.800 --> 00:22:30.880
icons, you'll probably see
them change over time as well.

450
00:22:30.880 --> 00:22:34.000
But we're going to actually see more,
but not in this episode.

451
00:22:34.000 --> 00:22:38.060
So signing off for Office Pro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

452
00:22:38.060 --> 00:22:39.180
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

453
00:22:39.180 --> 00:22:44.082
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Word 2016 Advanced shows.

454
00:22:44.082 --> 00:22:54.082
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss the purpose of and explain how to use SmartArt in Word. Vonne shows how to add SmartArt from the different galleries and then add shapes and text. She shows how to format individual shapes and/or the whole SmartArt using styles as well as how to resize, wrap text, and align within a document.
episodes.title: Smart Art
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.939
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.939 --> 00:00:09.573
>> Welcome to another great episode,
right here on OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.573 --> 00:00:13.776
You're watching the Microsoft Word
2016 Advanced show.

4
00:00:13.776 --> 00:00:19.140
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
gonna be taking a look at Smart Art.

5
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:20.637
Very interesting topic.

6
00:00:20.637 --> 00:00:23.781
Sounds like there's some
intelligence involved in it,

7
00:00:23.781 --> 00:00:28.180
so we need to actually consult our own
smartypants herself, Ms. Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:28.180 --> 00:00:29.630
Vonne, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:29.630 --> 00:00:30.725
>> [LAUGH] Smartypants.

10
00:00:30.725 --> 00:00:31.837
>> [LAUGH]
>> I like that that.

11
00:00:31.837 --> 00:00:34.204
[LAUGH]
>> All right Vonne.

12
00:00:34.204 --> 00:00:35.600
So we've got asked a question.

13
00:00:35.600 --> 00:00:39.260
We've already talked about images,
we've talked about shapes.

14
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:42.413
Smart Art, how smart is it really?

15
00:00:42.413 --> 00:00:43.200
>> It's really smart.

16
00:00:43.200 --> 00:00:43.795
>> Is it?
Okay.

17
00:00:43.795 --> 00:00:45.424
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's nice because it makes us not

18
00:00:45.424 --> 00:00:46.383
really have to think.

19
00:00:46.383 --> 00:00:48.510
[LAUGH]
>> Well, that sounds pretty good.

20
00:00:48.510 --> 00:00:50.340
>> What exactly is it?

21
00:00:50.340 --> 00:00:55.632
Smart Art is, well, shapes that
are being smart for us, [LAUGH] and

22
00:00:55.632 --> 00:01:00.752
it's really just it's graphical
representation of our data.

23
00:01:00.752 --> 00:01:02.870
Let's say we have a list.

24
00:01:02.870 --> 00:01:06.424
We have the different
departments within our company.

25
00:01:06.424 --> 00:01:07.939
We have our hosts.

26
00:01:07.939 --> 00:01:09.332
We have our switchers.

27
00:01:09.332 --> 00:01:11.616
We have our customer service.

28
00:01:11.616 --> 00:01:13.067
We have our developers.

29
00:01:13.067 --> 00:01:14.198
We could go ahead and

30
00:01:14.198 --> 00:01:16.748
list those out in just a bulleted list,-
>> Right.

31
00:01:16.748 --> 00:01:17.950
>> That's fine.

32
00:01:17.950 --> 00:01:23.102
But wouldn't it be kind of cute and
smart if we had like some colored

33
00:01:23.102 --> 00:01:27.708
blocks with each one of our
departments with the name in it?

34
00:01:27.708 --> 00:01:31.482
It just adds more flare,
more pieces of flare to our document,

35
00:01:31.482 --> 00:01:35.557
to just kind of gussy it up a lit
little bit, as I, my favorite term-

36
00:01:35.557 --> 00:01:36.359
>> [LAUGH]

37
00:01:36.359 --> 00:01:38.390
>> If you watched the Word essential show,

38
00:01:38.390 --> 00:01:41.915
we talked about that in a dinner
conversation I would have my father all

39
00:01:41.915 --> 00:01:44.603
the time,
he'd always bring words to the table, and

40
00:01:44.603 --> 00:01:46.390
ostentatious and-
>> and

41
00:01:46.390 --> 00:01:49.865
gussy
>> Gussy and ossiferous.

42
00:01:49.865 --> 00:01:52.285
>> [LAUGH] Okay, sure.

43
00:01:52.285 --> 00:01:55.780
>> [LAUGH] So those are the one I, for
some reason, remember throughout my,

44
00:01:55.780 --> 00:01:59.183
it was most in my high school years,
but anyway, I digress yet again.

45
00:01:59.183 --> 00:02:00.615
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's again,

46
00:02:00.615 --> 00:02:03.910
just art that's going to give us
just a little bit of a leg up and

47
00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:05.905
the nice thing is, it does it all for us.

48
00:02:05.905 --> 00:02:10.510
In the other ones we did go ahead and
create shapes and then we we grouped more

49
00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:15.440
together, and and did things like that,
but here it's all grouped shapes.

50
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:19.120
So we can still go ahead and
format them the same way that we did

51
00:02:19.120 --> 00:02:22.120
formatting our shapes individually,
but its all one entity and

52
00:02:22.120 --> 00:02:27.060
I can move it around, and I can add and
remove shapes really easily.

53
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:30.858
>> Now Vonne, the idea of the Smart Art
really sounds like there's a purpose

54
00:02:30.858 --> 00:02:34.590
behind it, at least from the examples
that your talking about.

55
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:38.081
The idea is not only to have words
available, but to actually even show

56
00:02:38.081 --> 00:02:41.632
a graphic that might show
the interrelationship between these items,

57
00:02:41.632 --> 00:02:45.536
as well as actually just saying look if we
need to change we can change it without

58
00:02:45.536 --> 00:02:47.094
having to change everything.

59
00:02:47.094 --> 00:02:50.860
So even in just what we were talking about
in a previous episode about stacking,

60
00:02:50.860 --> 00:02:54.568
we really don't have to worry about that
too much because it really does help us

61
00:02:54.568 --> 00:02:55.370
out in that way.

62
00:02:55.370 --> 00:02:57.069
So Vonne take us to it.

63

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee present the foundational knowledge and basic terminology associated with tables in Word.  They discuss the importance of understanding the different mouse cursor icons to able to select the right table element for formatting and table manipulation.  They also demonstrate how to treat a table as a graphical element in a Word document.
episodes.title: Tables: Introduction

00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:22.000
So, when you have a table,
a table is comprised of rows and columns.

27
00:01:22.000 --> 00:01:25.260
Where rows and
columns intersect is known as a cell.

28
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:28.623
So you have cells where you
put your information into.

29
00:01:28.623 --> 00:01:31.513
That's where you put in your text,
and then you can format,

30
00:01:31.513 --> 00:01:33.620
and do all those wonderful things.

31
00:01:33.620 --> 00:01:35.530
Now, how many rows and
columns do you want?

32
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:39.370
That's really up to you, and
what you need the information to say.

33
00:01:39.370 --> 00:01:44.260

specifically, is that this top cell.

34
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:49.190
This goes all the way across the three
columns that we have in this table,

35
00:01:49.190 --> 00:01:50.750
this is known as a merged cell.

36
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:55.860
You're taking multiple cells, merging
them together to create one large cell.

37
00:01:55.860 --> 00:01:58.500
Now it doesn't have to be at the top,
it could be anywhere,

38
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:01.298
doesn't have to be
across the entire table.

39
00:02:01.298 --> 00:02:04.680
No, you could merge two
cells in two columns, or

40
00:02:04.680 --> 00:02:07.400
you can merge two cells in two rows.

41
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:09.690
Doesn't matter the amount or the size,

42
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:14.250
it just matters how much you want to
make one big cell out of these things.

43
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:15.960
So that would be a merged cell.

44
00:02:15.960 --> 00:02:20.400
Then you could go ahead and
go crazy with your table layout,

45
00:02:20.400 --> 00:02:24.430
you can change things like the row height,
the column width.

46

stay tuned with us for another episode.

we'll go ahead and sign out.

465
00:23:02.809 --> 00:23:04.552
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

466
00:23:04.552 --> 00:23:05.700
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

467
00:23:05.700 --> 00:23:07.997
>> See you next time here on Office ProTV.

468
00:23:07.997 --> 00:23:13.590
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee continue to explore tables in Word 2016. Vonne shows how to insert rows and columns, as well as adding text into cells. The ladies discuss why one would or would not want to merge cells, split cells, or split tables. They also explain several ways to modify a table layout such as: specifying height and width, auto-fit options, distribute rows/columns, cell alignment/margins, text directions and more!
episodes.title: Tables: Create and Layout

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne discuss how to convert text into table content and vice versa. Vonne shows how to insert ready-made tables using Quick Tables and how to create custom tables using the draw table command. Vonne also demonstrates how to calculate totals using basic formulas, sorting data by single and multiple levels, and inserting an Excel spreadsheet as an embedded object.
episodes.title: Tables: Create and Layout Part 2

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach discuss how to format tables and cell content. Vonne shows how to apply borders and shading to selected cells using the Table Tools contextual tabs as well as text formatting from the Home tab on the Ribbon. They also demonstrate how to format using styles and how to clear formatting completely.
episodes.title: Tables: Format and Design

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach introduce the foundations of charts in Word 2016.  Vonne demonstrates how to insert charts and input the category and series values for the charts. She also shows how to change the chart type, edit and update chart data, modify chart layouts with Quick layouts, and add chart elements such as data tables and data labels.
episodes.title: Charts

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach continue with charts in Word 2016. In this episode, they focus on formatting chart elements individually with fills and outlines as well as with styles. They also show how to format specific options of chart elements from the format pane. They then explore different type of charts and show how to create and format pie charts.
episodes.title: Charts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Zach explore using text as graphical elements.  Vonne shows how to insert, format, and modify a text box.  She also shows how to create multiple linked text boxes to flow text from one text box to another. They also show how to insert WordArt as an individual element and how to create hyperlinks in a Word document to external webpages and files as well as internal within a document to headings and bookmarks.
episodes.title: Graphical Text Objects

00:21:21.270 --> 00:21:22.970
That's exactly what I want.

380
00:21:22.970 --> 00:21:25.470
The text, that's what I have selected.

381
00:21:25.470 --> 00:21:27.610
So this is the text display.

382
00:21:27.610 --> 00:21:30.740
But the address, and
I'm just gonna paste this in here.

383
00:21:30.740 --> 00:21:32.600
That's where I want the link to go into.

384
00:21:32.600 --> 00:21:37.150
It's kind of like behind
the scenes of this selected text.

385
00:21:37.150 --> 00:21:41.900
And when I click OK, it's still a link,
it's still blue, it's still underlined.

386
00:21:41.900 --> 00:21:43.760
If I hold my control key and

387
00:21:43.760 --> 00:21:46.580
click it, it's gonna take me
out to that particular website.

388
00:21:46.580 --> 00:21:49.680
So it doesn't always have
to display the text of

389
00:21:49.680 --> 00:21:53.290
they're actually URLs especially
if you have a really long URL and

390
00:21:53.290 --> 00:21:57.710
you don't wanna to say there's like
visit our site, go ahead and do that.

391
00:21:57.710 --> 00:22:01.610
Second way that i had just showed you.

392
00:22:01.610 --> 00:22:05.350
And how to add a hyperlink to your text.

393
00:22:05.350 --> 00:22:08.710
Now that's of course you
have going out to a website.

394
00:22:08.710 --> 00:22:12.560
Totally fine, but as you can see from
that Insert Hyperlink dialogue box,

395
00:22:12.560 --> 00:22:16.520
there's some other things that
we could do of jumping around.

396
00:22:16.520 --> 00:22:21.090
And one of them was like hey, what if I
want to visit another file on my computer.

397
00:22:21.090 --> 00:22:24.420
So let's say, I don't know,
turn the corner.

398
00:22:24.420 --> 00:22:26.262
I'm just randomly picking text.

399
00:22:26.262 --> 00:22:26.772
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

400
00:22:26.772 --> 00:22:29.700
>> I want turn the corner to be linked to

401
00:22:29.700 --> 00:22:32.210
another file on my computer.

402
00:22:32.210 --> 00:22:35.770
So same thing, insert link, there.

403
00:22:35.770 --> 00:22:37.080
I could have also right clicked.

404
00:22:38.220 --> 00:22:42.970
Existing file, and
maybe I want it to link to Christmas Cats.

405
00:22:42.970 --> 00:22:46.820
That's just, right so I click OK,
and it does the same thing.

406
00:22:46.820 --> 00:22:47.400
>> Wise choice.

407
00:22:47.400 --> 00:22:48.969
>> Yes, let's see what that looks like.

408
00:22:49.970 --> 00:22:50.640
Preview of like.

409
00:22:52.350 --> 00:22:54.070
Yeah, there is Ms. Felicia.

410
00:22:54.070 --> 00:22:56.970
>> Yeah, so we'll be talking about
this when we talk about templates,

411
00:22:58.020 --> 00:22:59.220
in this series.

412
00:22:59.220 --> 00:23:03.050
But it jumped over and
it opened up a file exactly like it said.

413
00:23:03.050 --> 00:23:03.930
Think about this though.

414
00:23:03.930 --> 00:23:08.160
What if I sent this to you,
and I emailed it to you.

415
00:23:08.160 --> 00:23:10.700
And you opened up this file,
and you clicked on it.

416
00:23:10.700 --> 00:23:12.520
Well I didn't send you the Christmas Cats.

417
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:15.920
And maybe the Christmas Cats doesn't
live on your desktop obviously.

418
00:23:15.920 --> 00:23:19.400
So if I send that you do
have to be very aware of

419
00:23:19.400 --> 00:23:22.030
linking to files that everybody
would have access to.

420
00:23:22.030 --> 00:23:22.540
>> Okay.
>> So

421
00:23:22.540 --> 00:23:26.910
this would be something like if you're
in a large organization that has files

422
00:23:26.910 --> 00:23:31.440
on a shared network drive,
everybody can get to it.

423
00:23:31.440 --> 00:23:34.790
But not everybody has
the permissions to do.

424
00:23:34.790 --> 00:23:37.910
If it's for you, cuz maybe you
wanna use this as a reference,

425
00:23:37.910 --> 00:23:41.480
cuz maybe that Christmas Cats
file has a list of

426
00:23:41.480 --> 00:23:45.530
all of the pricing that you use
in a document all the time.

427
00:23:45.530 --> 00:23:48.410
This is really good if you're
using an invoice template.

428
00:23:49.660 --> 00:23:53.360
I keep prefacing ooh, templates,
templates, templates are really cool.

429
00:23:53.360 --> 00:23:54.629
So if you make your own and

430
00:23:54.629 --> 00:23:58.870
I want to be able to, I don't remember
all our customer numbers in this invoice.

431
00:23:58.870 --> 00:24:02.832
But I'm the only one that's going
to be writing up invoices and

432
00:24:02.832 --> 00:24:07.191
I want to be able really quickly
Click that link, open up a document.

433
00:24:07.191 --> 00:24:08.943
Let's say an Excel file or what not.

434
00:24:08.943 --> 00:24:10.400
There's that customer number.

435
00:24:10.400 --> 00:24:14.190
Copy and paste it into my Word document,
and then everything is ready to go.

436
00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:20.427
So if it's just for you, and the file's
never leaving, then go right for it.

437
00:24:20.427 --> 00:24:23.248
That was actually an example we
would always use in our templates.

438
00:24:23.248 --> 00:24:23.762
And you know what?

439
00:24:23.762 --> 00:24:25.247
Now that I think about it,
I think we're gonna go ahead and

440
00:24:25.247 --> 00:24:26.018
throw it in that episode too.

441
00:24:26.018 --> 00:24:26.628
[LAUGH]
>> Awesome!

442
00:24:26.628 --> 00:24:29.847
>> But
just different ways that you can, say,

443
00:24:29.847 --> 00:24:35.250
link to a file that doesn't require hey,
not everybody's gonna use it.

444
00:24:35.250 --> 00:24:37.380
All right, so
linking to a particular file.

445
00:24:37.380 --> 00:24:40.370
But then there's another thing
in that insert hyperlink

446
00:24:40.370 --> 00:24:44.790
dialog box that talks about going to
different places within your document.

447
00:24:44.790 --> 00:24:49.450
And there is a reason why I formatted
this particular Word file with headings.

448
00:24:49.450 --> 00:24:52.110
Well one, I think you should use styles
and headings all over the place.

449
00:24:52.110 --> 00:24:56.750
But it is referring to how to
jump around your document.

450
00:24:57.870 --> 00:25:01.410
Let's say I want this,
this is your text here.

451
00:25:01.410 --> 00:25:07.530
And I wanted it to jump down to this
particular section, the Queen of Hearts.

452
00:25:07.530 --> 00:25:09.080
I want it to jump down into here.

453
00:25:09.080 --> 00:25:11.634
Remember that whole continued on page,
or what have you?

454
00:25:11.634 --> 00:25:13.683
This is where, in those text boxes,

455
00:25:13.683 --> 00:25:17.200
you could start adding hyperlinks
within the same document.

456
00:25:17.200 --> 00:25:19.550
It doesn't have to go
outside your document.

457
00:25:20.790 --> 00:25:23.550
So you select the text, and
we're just gonna come back up.

458
00:25:23.550 --> 00:25:25.185
There we go.
We've got that text selected,

459
00:25:25.185 --> 00:25:27.750
cuz your text here makes so much sense.

460
00:25:27.750 --> 00:25:29.610
We will add our hyperlink.

461
00:25:30.910 --> 00:25:33.352
We're gonna go into
Place in this Document.

462
00:25:33.352 --> 00:25:37.444
And this is the big reason of why you
wanna use headings if you're using jumping

463
00:25:37.444 --> 00:25:39.874
around to different
places in your document.

464
00:25:39.874 --> 00:25:44.285
Because it's gonna know where to jump
to based on your heading levels.

465
00:25:44.285 --> 00:25:46.915
There's Down the Rabbit Hole,
Queen of Hearts.

466
00:25:46.915 --> 00:25:50.580
Notice it's pulling in our heading1s,
then our heading2s.

467
00:25:50.580 --> 00:25:52.780
It will go ahead and
do our heading3s and other ones,

468
00:25:52.780 --> 00:25:56.930
if you are using documents that
are formatting with that particular style.

469
00:25:56.930 --> 00:26:00.640
So if I wanted it to jump to
Queen of Hearts, I click OK.

470
00:26:01.650 --> 00:26:04.260
And now I Ctrl+click.

471
00:26:04.260 --> 00:26:08.430
It takes me directly down into
that part of the document.

472
00:26:08.430 --> 00:26:12.215
So I can use this to go back and
forth to different places.

473
00:26:12.215 --> 00:26:17.200
Sweet, but what if I wanted it to go to,

474
00:26:17.200 --> 00:26:20.900
I don't know, this particular page.

475
00:26:20.900 --> 00:26:24.666
This particular paragraph,
the baby grunted again.

476
00:26:24.666 --> 00:26:27.164
Okay, so I will then jump down here, but

477
00:26:27.164 --> 00:26:31.140
there is nothing that is connected
to this area of the document.

478
00:26:31.140 --> 00:26:34.280
There's no heading specifically for
this area, okay?

479
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:38.994
But I want to make it a destination for
me to get to it somehow,

480
00:26:38.994 --> 00:26:43.996
whether it's by navigation, or
in this sense, by hyperlink.

481
00:26:43.996 --> 00:26:47.180
This is known as a bookmark, okay?

482
00:26:47.180 --> 00:26:49.350
It's like we put a bookmark
in a regular book, right?

483
00:26:49.350 --> 00:26:51.370
I wanna make sure I get right
to this particular page.

484
00:26:51.370 --> 00:26:54.987
And especially sometimes you dog ear
the page down far enough to know what

485
00:26:54.987 --> 00:26:57.450
paragraph that you had stopped on.

486
00:26:57.450 --> 00:26:59.050
This is the same idea.

487
00:26:59.050 --> 00:27:04.950
I can insert my own kind of, this is
where I want to be, I put in a bookmark.

488
00:27:04.950 --> 00:27:07.700
So cursor, where you want it to go.

489
00:27:07.700 --> 00:27:11.620
And that's where, right on your link,
you've got bookmark.

490
00:27:11.620 --> 00:27:15.560
Works with hyperlinks that let you jump
to specific places in your document.

491
00:27:15.560 --> 00:27:17.040
I click my bookmark.

492
00:27:17.040 --> 00:27:19.810
I can name this,
we'll just name this baby.

493
00:27:19.810 --> 00:27:24.160
And this is sorting by name, because I
don't have any other bookmarks in here.

494
00:27:24.160 --> 00:27:25.930
If I'm not mistaken.

495
00:27:25.930 --> 00:27:28.030
Well you know what,
I think I can try it out.

496
00:27:28.030 --> 00:27:30.390
Baby paragraph.

497
00:27:30.390 --> 00:27:32.620
I wanna say it doesn't.

498
00:27:32.620 --> 00:27:34.490
Yes, okay, good.

499
00:27:34.490 --> 00:27:36.290
>> Good.
>> Some memory coming back.

500
00:27:36.290 --> 00:27:38.810
It doesn't like if you use spaces, okay?

501
00:27:38.810 --> 00:27:41.810
Notice how it does not let
me hit that Add button?

502
00:27:41.810 --> 00:27:44.560
But if I had said baby underscore.

503
00:27:44.560 --> 00:27:49.830
So it has to have no spaces
in the name of your bookmark.

504
00:27:49.830 --> 00:27:52.260
I'm not sure if it will hold
special characters either.

505
00:27:52.260 --> 00:27:56.019
But the nice thing is, you could tell that
if it doesn't give you the add button,

506
00:27:56.019 --> 00:27:59.559
then you're not conforming to its naming
convention that it likes to have,

507
00:27:59.559 --> 00:28:00.804
which would be no spaces.

508
00:28:00.804 --> 00:28:05.351
So add a dash, or an underscore in
this case, to, say, baby_paragraph.

509
00:28:05.351 --> 00:28:08.580
I hit Add, and then it's just added.

510
00:28:08.580 --> 00:28:10.525
My cursor was there,
that's where it's going to go.

511
00:28:10.525 --> 00:28:12.058
Let's scroll back up to the top.

512
00:28:12.058 --> 00:28:13.676
I should have just did a Ctrl+Home.

513
00:28:13.676 --> 00:28:17.280
And then, maybe we'll say down,
down, down.

514
00:28:17.280 --> 00:28:22.270
I want these words to jump
down to that baby paragraph.

515
00:28:23.410 --> 00:28:29.190
Select the text, come into
Insert Hyperlink > Place in this Document.

516
00:28:29.190 --> 00:28:31.050
And look right there, down at the bottom.

517
00:28:31.050 --> 00:28:35.420
Because it's giving me the headings, or
it could go to the top of the document,

518
00:28:35.420 --> 00:28:37.230
that's just a default one.

519
00:28:37.230 --> 00:28:42.738
I wanna go to that particular place right
there, click OK, that becomes a hyperlink.

520
00:28:42.738 --> 00:28:44.750
Hold your Ctrl key down, click, and

521
00:28:44.750 --> 00:28:48.770
it goes specifically down to
that spot that I had bookmarked.

522
00:28:48.770 --> 00:28:51.615
I don't have to always have
it connected to a heading,

523
00:28:51.615 --> 00:28:55.380
cuz maybe you don't have a heading for
it to attach to.

524
00:28:55.380 --> 00:28:59.020
But you really need it to go to
that particular destination.

525
00:28:59.020 --> 00:29:04.860
Make a bookmark at that destination, and
then go ahead and insert that hyperlink.

526
00:29:04.860 --> 00:29:05.566
>> It's magical.

527
00:29:05.566 --> 00:29:07.014
>> [LAUGH] It is!

528
00:29:07.014 --> 00:29:11.619
[SOUND] And I believe that comes to the
end of my notes of covering everything.

529
00:29:11.619 --> 00:29:13.074
>> [LAUGH]
>> I had to make sure.

530
00:29:13.074 --> 00:29:14.990
Yep, all those three parts.

531
00:29:14.990 --> 00:29:19.910
So those are the different things that
you can do with text as graphics,

532
00:29:19.910 --> 00:29:23.400
throw on some hyperlinks that
really aren't necessarily graphics.

533
00:29:23.400 --> 00:29:26.715
But I guess you could have it within
a graphical element, like that Word Art or

534
00:29:26.715 --> 00:29:29.632
that particular shape, and
just have it jump to different places.

535
00:29:29.632 --> 00:29:30.967
>> Marvelous job as usual Vonne.

536
00:29:30.967 --> 00:29:32.495
>> Thank you very much.
>> Thank you very much.

537
00:29:32.495 --> 00:29:34.672
And this is Word 2016 Advanced.

538
00:29:34.672 --> 00:29:37.170
There's a whole bunch of video content for
you to explore.

539
00:29:37.170 --> 00:29:39.182
And Vonne is a great teacher, isn't she?

540
00:29:39.182 --> 00:29:40.336
>> [LAUGH]
>> Very nice.

541
00:29:40.336 --> 00:29:42.816
Hey, an Office Pro is always learning.

542
00:29:42.816 --> 00:29:44.592
That means you too [LAUGH].

543
00:29:44.592 --> 00:29:46.334
I'm Zach Memos.

544
00:29:46.334 --> 00:29:47.392
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

545
00:29:47.392 --> 00:29:48.560
>> And we'll see you soon.

546
00:29:48.560 --> 00:29:52.363
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the use of templates. They explain the commonly misused and misunderstood concept of a template and how to correctly use a template in Word.  They create documents from the built-in templates from Microsoft as well as creating a custom template from an existing document. They identify the default location of templates within the operating system and the importance of the normal template in Word.
episodes.title: Templates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:06.791
[SOUND]
Greetings everyone and

2
00:00:06.791 --> 00:00:09.310
welcome to another exciting
episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.310 --> 00:00:12.240
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:12.240 --> 00:00:15.430
well, we're coming back at you with
more advanced Word In particular,

5
00:00:15.430 --> 00:00:17.240
we're gonna be looking at templates today.

6
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:20.470
And here to help us is our very
own Word wizard, Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:20.470 --> 00:00:21.270
How are you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:24.698
>> I'm doing fantastic,
I'm ready to drum up some wizardry today.

9
00:00:24.698 --> 00:00:27.680
[LAUGH] And
we're gonna be talking about templates.

10
00:00:27.680 --> 00:00:31.770
Now templates is one of those, I feel,
kind of a misconstrued word and

11
00:00:31.770 --> 00:00:34.590
concept when it comes to Word.

12
00:00:34.590 --> 00:00:40.330
So I'm gonna help clarify what exactly is
a template, how to use them correctly,

13
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:45.270
and then explore some of the pre-made
templates that come with Word and how we

14
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:49.600
can utilize them to just kind of help make
us things like business cards or resumes.

15
00:00:49.600 --> 00:00:52.240
Like, hey I need to go ahead and
make my resume I don't even know what it's

16
00:00:52.240 --> 00:00:54.330
supposed to look like,
they have a template for that.

17
00:00:54.330 --> 00:00:57.540
It's kind of like hey they have an app for
that, there's probably a template for

18
00:00:57.540 --> 00:00:58.580
that in Word.

19
00:00:58.580 --> 00:01:01.530
So we're gonna be exploring that but
before we get into it

Justin what do you think in general
terms when you think of a template?

21
00:01:06.300 --> 00:01:09.150
>> So when I think of a template I
almost think of a cookie cutter.

22
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:11.800
I don't know maybe I like
associations with food.

23
00:01:11.800 --> 00:01:15.970
But like if I want a star shaped cookie I
get out the star shaped cookie cutter and

24
00:01:15.970 --> 00:01:18.000
stamp out a bunch of star shape cookies.

25
00:01:18.000 --> 00:01:19.950
So that's kind of what I
think of as the template.

26
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:22.950
>> All my shows ended up talking
about either cats, food, or

27
00:01:22.950 --> 00:01:26.760
middle school traumas so
I totally can relate with that.

28
00:01:26.760 --> 00:01:29.450
But it's the whole idea that you're
taking the cookie cutter and

29
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:30.150
you're making them out.

30
00:01:30.150 --> 00:01:34.810
But you're not eating
the cookie cutter itself.

31
00:01:34.810 --> 00:01:36.480
You're eating the cookie right?

32
00:01:36.480 --> 00:01:38.295
I hope you're doing that.

33
00:01:38.295 --> 00:01:42.160
[LAUGH] So that's the whole idea here is
that when you're working with templates

34
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:45.810
is that you're not really
working in the template itself,

35
00:01:45.810 --> 00:01:48.810
you're making it like a cookie cutter or
a stamp.

36
00:01:48.810 --> 00:01:52.720
I like to think of it as a rubber stamp
to where you have that, you go ahead and

37
00:01:52.720 --> 00:01:53.780
get it all inked up,

38
00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:57.360
you take a blank piece of paper, you put
the stamp on it, and then there you go.

39
00:01:57.360 --> 00:02:01.490
And then maybe you write in the little
pieces that maybe the stamp has little

40
00:02:01.490 --> 00:02:02.920
places for you to write stuff in.

41
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:04.910
And that's the actual document.

42
00:02:04.910 --> 00:02:08.440
It's not the stamp but
the stamp is what started it.

43
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:13.290
And that's how templates are usually or
what they're supposed to be used in Word.

44
00:02:13.290 --> 00:02:16.340
Now I say supposed to because

45
00:02:16.340 --> 00:02:20.650
I've had a lot of people say I have this
template for you let me go ahead and

46
00:02:20.650 --> 00:02:25.010
send it and then they send it to me and
it's nothing but a Word document.

47
00:02:26.450 --> 00:02:28.460
And I'm like all right,
I'll let you slide.

48
00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:30.370
Cuz it's like that's your starting point,
right?

49
00:02:30.370 --> 00:02:31.230
>> Now wait a minute Vonne,

50
00:02:31.230 --> 00:02:34.380
are you telling me that's
not an appropriate template?

51
00:02:34.380 --> 00:02:35.810
I've been doing it wrong the whole time.

52
00:02:35.810 --> 00:02:36.760
>> Yeah, kind of.

53
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:40.755
But let me show you, how about that.

54
00:02:40.755 --> 00:02:43.930
[LAUGH] So let's go ahead and
get into our computer.

55
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:47.000
And I don't have Word
even started right now so

56
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:51.140
I just wanted to kind of go from
the beginning and let's fire it up.

57
00:02:51.140 --> 00:02:55.000
And actually this start
screen that you have

58
00:02:55.000 --> 00:02:58.980
all of these things that you're
looking at these are templates that

59
00:02:58.980 --> 00:03:04.060
are pre-made in Word that

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the world of Quick Parts and AutoText and how they can help automate insertion of commonly used elements into a document. They also show where to add and manage document properties and how they relate to adding fields and/or Quick Parts into your Word files.
episodes.title: Quick Parts

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne demonstrate how to create, edit, and delete macros. They explain how macros can be helpful in automating repeatable steps, but also emphasize the potential security risk macros can pose if executed from an unknown source.
episodes.title: Macros

00:21:01.430 --> 00:21:02.260
Yeah that's perfect.

399
00:21:02.260 --> 00:21:03.400
I'm so glad we did that.

400
00:21:03.400 --> 00:21:06.501
All right, so
yes you can do it too, [SOUND].

401
00:21:06.501 --> 00:21:08.990
So now it works, awesome.

402
00:21:08.990 --> 00:21:14.080
And I went in and edited in the VBA
code and if I wanted I could delete it.

403
00:21:14.080 --> 00:21:17.610
And now the other one I wanted to show
you is that it was great to go ahead and

404
00:21:17.610 --> 00:21:22.050
click on Developer and
go to macros and run the recording.

405
00:21:22.050 --> 00:21:26.040
But wouldn't it be cute to have just like
a little button right here for me to just

406
00:21:26.040 --> 00:21:32.680
boop, just click it and I can perform
that macro on any document at any time.

407
00:21:32.680 --> 00:21:34.570
That's where were going to
be customizing the ribbon.

408
00:21:34.570 --> 00:21:36.540
Now this isn't really
a part of recording macros,

409
00:21:36.540 --> 00:21:42.460
I just wanted to kind of extend it into
making it a really accessible button.

410
00:21:42.460 --> 00:21:45.370
So we come over here to File,
we're gonna go to Options.

411
00:21:46.490 --> 00:21:49.420
We're gonna customize
the quick access toolbar.

412
00:21:49.420 --> 00:21:55.070
Now this macro that I have, well it
is a command but where does it live?

413
00:21:55.070 --> 00:21:59.420
If you drop this down,
there's a whole section for macros.

414
00:21:59.420 --> 00:22:04.620
Cool, so that's why we should go ahead and
put those macros into the ether,

415
00:22:04.620 --> 00:22:05.820
if you want to say.

416
00:22:05.820 --> 00:22:10.620
We put it into that normal template,
that dotm rather than

417
00:22:10.620 --> 00:22:16.210
just that particular document so that
way I can share it with everybody else.

418
00:22:16.210 --> 00:22:19.367
Select that macro that I have, add it.

419
00:22:19.367 --> 00:22:22.909
But now that normal,
that doesn't really say much for me and

420
00:22:22.909 --> 00:22:24.720
I don't really like the icon.

421
00:22:24.720 --> 00:22:28.237
So you can come into the Modify
button down at the bottom,

422
00:22:28.237 --> 00:22:30.156
and when you click the Modify.

423
00:22:30.156 --> 00:22:33.170
What should we choose, Justin?

424
00:22:33.170 --> 00:22:33.798
What about that little smiley face?

425
00:22:33.798 --> 00:22:36.199
Yep, you gotta go emoji every time.

426
00:22:36.199 --> 00:22:39.550
If you have a choice, it's not really
a choice if you have an emoji.

427
00:22:39.550 --> 00:22:43.667
Yeah, exactly [LAUGH] what
could be happier than some,

428
00:22:43.667 --> 00:22:46.090
we have some balloons, right.

429
00:22:46.090 --> 00:22:49.425
Balloons and do not copy,
that just screams smiles.

430
00:22:49.425 --> 00:22:54.088
[LAUGH] And
I can name this macro layout and

431
00:22:54.088 --> 00:22:57.250
name it whatever you want.

432
00:22:57.250 --> 00:23:00.770
Click OK, and so
I can edit that particular button.

433
00:23:00.770 --> 00:23:03.260
Notice you can,
well you can't modify that particular one.

434
00:23:03.260 --> 00:23:06.568
But some of your ones, especially
the macros, you could go ahead and

435
00:23:06.568 --> 00:23:07.606
modify that button.

436
00:23:07.606 --> 00:23:10.071
We click OK, awesome.

437
00:23:10.071 --> 00:23:13.204
And then if I opened up
a file of whatever one,

438
00:23:13.204 --> 00:23:17.010
let's go with this quick parts,
okay, just for fun.

439
00:23:17.010 --> 00:23:21.309
We click that button and
then you see that it will, ta da,

440
00:23:21.309 --> 00:23:24.905
went ahead and
apply that macro just like that.

441
00:23:24.905 --> 00:23:28.940
And that was a document I already created,
that was not a file new.

442
00:23:28.940 --> 00:23:32.250
So I wanted to show you that it's for
all document,

443
00:23:32.250 --> 00:23:36.662
for all active documents, and
new documents that I could run this.

444
00:23:36.662 --> 00:23:42.040
So I hope it's making your mind run
a little bit too of all the possibilities

445
00:23:42.040 --> 00:23:49.590
that you could do with using macros to
help you make your life so much easier.

446
00:23:49.590 --> 00:23:53.688
Yeah, macros are definitely something
that, well, I can see the power in them.

447
00:23:53.688 --> 00:23:57.780
And well, Vaughn, before we go is there
anything else that you would like to add?

448
00:23:57.780 --> 00:24:01.600
Just really kind of getting into,
like I said in the beginning.

449
00:24:01.600 --> 00:24:02.770
When do I use a template?

450
00:24:02.770 --> 00:24:03.780
When do I use a quick part?

451
00:24:03.780 --> 00:24:05.340
When do I use a macro?

452
00:24:05.340 --> 00:24:07.640
You do have to kind of
compartmentalize it.

453
00:24:07.640 --> 00:24:10.400
And you can combine them,
you can put macros in a template.

454
00:24:10.400 --> 00:24:13.629
But if you are going to put a macro in
a template, it does need to be a macro

455
00:24:14.880 --> 00:24:17.480
enabled template, and
you need to make sure it has that dotm.

456
00:24:18.730 --> 00:24:22.650
And that is one of those in the drop
down with the Save As Type,

457
00:24:22.650 --> 00:24:26.600
there will be template and
there will be macro enabled template.

458
00:24:26.600 --> 00:24:27.550
Same with your document.

459
00:24:27.550 --> 00:24:32.640
If you are saving a macro in a document,
you don't save as a docx.

460
00:24:34.270 --> 00:24:38.090
There is a choice in the drop down for
macro enabled documents.

461
00:24:38.090 --> 00:24:42.610
That would be the biggest part is if
you're saving these within templates or

462
00:24:42.610 --> 00:24:46.670
documents, get that m at
the end of the file name to

463
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:50.440
make sure you have the full power
of what a macro can do for you.

464
00:24:50.440 --> 00:24:51.970
Well there you have it, right.

465
00:24:51.970 --> 00:24:55.840
We can have our very own macros that make
our workflow, well, more performant.

466
00:24:55.840 --> 00:24:59.120
But then you can also store macros that
you distribute through other people.

467
00:24:59.120 --> 00:25:03.160
Do keep in mind that could be a possible
vector for a security exploit, so

468
00:25:03.160 --> 00:25:05.950
if you get them always be aware
of who they're sent from.

469
00:25:05.950 --> 00:25:07.510
But thank you so much, Vaughn.

470
00:25:07.510 --> 00:25:10.150
But I think we have run out of time for
this episode, but

471
00:25:10.150 --> 00:25:12.660
we've got more advanced
Word coming at you.

472
00:25:12.660 --> 00:25:16.590
But for now, signing off for OfficePro TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

473
00:25:16.590 --> 00:25:17.240
And I'm Vaughn Smith.

474
00:25:17.240 --> 00:25:18.851
And we'll see you next time.

475
00:25:18.851 --> 00:25:24.710
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss how to create linked objects in Word, specifically links to Excel content. Additionally, Vonne demonstrates how to update links, change source, and break links.
episodes.title: Linked Objects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.587
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.587 --> 00:00:10.270
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of OFFICEPRO.TV.

3
00:00:10.270 --> 00:00:11.730
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:11.730 --> 00:00:15.280
in today's episode,
we'll work back with more advanced work.

5
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:18.160
I'm excited and I know you are as well,
and in particular,

6
00:00:18.160 --> 00:00:20.080
we're gonna be looking at linked objects.

7
00:00:20.080 --> 00:00:22.650
Now, I don't know if this has
anything to do with high rule or

8
00:00:22.650 --> 00:00:24.760
the masters Sword of the triforce, but

9
00:00:24.760 --> 00:00:29.650
here to help us kind of find our way,
is our one and only Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:29.650 --> 00:00:30.570
How you doing today, Vonne?
