00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:31.832
>> Are those Zelda references?

12
00:00:31.832 --> 00:00:33.752
[LAUGH]
>> Those were Zelda references.

13
00:00:33.752 --> 00:00:34.335
>> I was like.

14
00:00:34.335 --> 00:00:37.010
[LAUGH] I heard master sword in there,
and I was like.

15
00:00:37.010 --> 00:00:40.070
And I'm like, A, B, A, B, up, down, up,
down, left, right, left, right, start?

16
00:00:40.070 --> 00:00:41.860
Or [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, who knows?

17
00:00:41.860 --> 00:00:42.652
It's nostalgia.

18
00:00:42.652 --> 00:00:43.400
Nostalgia.
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:44.540
>> I don't need you judging me.

20
00:00:45.610 --> 00:00:46.710
>> Hey, I'm right there with you.

21
00:00:46.710 --> 00:00:48.070
So I totally feel you.

22
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:51.350
So unfortunately we're not gonna be
talking about the Legend of Zelda because

23
00:00:51.350 --> 00:00:54.490
that's probably as far as I can
get with that particular game.

24
00:00:54.490 --> 00:00:58.224
Now give me some Lolo 2,
ooh, then we're talking.

25
00:00:58.224 --> 00:01:02.646
But no, we're talking about
linked objects in Word.

26
00:01:02.646 --> 00:01:07.390
So why is this in the automation
section of this show?

27
00:01:07.390 --> 00:01:09.390
Well it’s because if you think about it,

28
00:01:09.390 --> 00:01:12.970
if I can get information
from another source and

29
00:01:12.970 --> 00:01:17.395
have it update itself automatically,
that could save me a lot of time.

30
00:01:17.395 --> 00:01:18.345
Let's take an example.

31
00:01:18.345 --> 00:01:22.345
Say we're doing an annual report in Word,
because it's a word processor,

32
00:01:22.345 --> 00:01:27.055
and we're gonna be getting a lot of
information from our Excel files.

33
00:01:27.055 --> 00:01:29.505
And maybe even let's take it,
cuz annual report,

34
00:01:29.505 --> 00:01:31.345
that's something that
only happens once a year.

35
00:01:31.345 --> 00:01:35.445
What if we took this, maybe you're doing
a weekly report or a quarterly report

36
00:01:35.445 --> 00:01:40.130
that you're going to be needing that data
in the same data set, but you're gonna

37
00:01:40.130 --> 00:01:44.790
need to have it refresh every time that
you have to create that particular report.

38
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:46.562
Okay, so we will go from annual to weekly.

39
00:01:46.562 --> 00:01:51.053
But the idea is we will be taking the
content from Excel and I would normally

40
00:01:51.053 --> 00:01:56.330
just go ahead and copy and paste, and
paste the information right into Excel.

41
00:01:56.330 --> 00:01:58.260
But again, what are the changes?

42
00:01:58.260 --> 00:01:59.390
I don't need to go back, and

43
00:01:59.390 --> 00:02:03.940
like, let me go ahead and copy that again,
delete it out, paste it again.

44
00:02:03.940 --> 00:02:08.010
What if you just had it
connected to that source?

45
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:13.000
Connected to the Excel table, or
I guess you could say it's table.

46
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:15.360
That Excel content, that chart.

47
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:16.880
Any of that information from there,

48
00:02:16.880 --> 00:02:20.900
and all I have to do is come into Word,
open the file up.

49
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:24.610
And then it will show, and reflect any
of the changes I've made in those Excel

50
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:27.070
documents, right in my Word document.

51
00:02:27.070 --> 00:02:27.990
That's pretty cool.

52
00:02:27.990 --> 00:02:30.330
>> Now, I could definitely see this
being something where I need to,

53
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:32.120
maybe I have some investors.

54
00:02:32.120 --> 00:02:35.650
Right, and I have to provide them with
a report of about profit and loss.

55
00:02:35.650 --> 00:02:38.430
On a monthly basis, and
I have to provide justification for

56
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:40.680
anything that seems out of the ordinary,
right?

57
00:02:40.680 --> 00:02:45.110
You have kinda these standard metrics for
a PnL, but I don't wanna have to go and

58
00:02:45.110 --> 00:02:46.620
copy and paste that all the time.

59
00:02:46.620 --> 00:02:49.240
I have important things to do
like making our PnL better.

60
00:02:49.240 --> 00:02:53.120
And well, it would be nice just to have
that prepopulate, give my justification,

61
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:55.470
ship that off, and
kinda automate that part of my day.

62
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:57.880
>> Exactly.
And then you can go play Legends of Zelda.

63
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:02.747
>> Exactly, there is nothing better
than finishing up your PnL report and

64
00:03:02.747 --> 00:03:04.869
going back to link to the past.

65
00:03:04.869 --> 00:03:06.768
>> [LAUGH ] Exactly.

66
00:03:06.768 --> 00:03:10.550
That's a perfect example of some
ways that you might want to do this.

67
00:03:10.550 --> 00:03:13.060
Now I am concentrating
specifically on Excel

68
00:03:13.060 --> 00:03:18.300
information because that's probably
the most common type of linked object.

69
00:03:18.300 --> 00:03:21.950
You can link, well you actually really
can't link to a PowerPoint presentation

70
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:25.590
because then it just becomes, it's just
an image, whatever, slides you're on.

71
00:03:25.590 --> 00:03:28.950
So it really is going to
work best with that Excel.

72
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:31.640
I can see maybe Access, but even that

73
00:03:31.640 --> 00:03:35.270
I think is pushing the envelope a little
bit, so we're gonna concentrate on that.

74
00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:40.560
I have an example of an already
created linked document in Word.

75
00:03:40.560 --> 00:03:44.410
It's called Linked Example,
so if I open this up.

76
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:47.830
You're gonna look at this and say,
well that just looks like a regular table.

77
00:03:47.830 --> 00:03:50.946
We've been talking about
the activity of Mr and

78
00:03:50.946 --> 00:03:55.910
little over here, but
this is the same thing, right?

79
00:03:55.910 --> 00:03:57.410
Well, no.

80
00:03:57.410 --> 00:04:02.102
One because I know I made this document,
but there's gonna be some bigger

81
00:04:02.102 --> 00:04:06.732
indicators to you of hey, this isn't
just a created table within Word.

82
00:04:06.732 --> 00:04:11.334
If I click on it, the first thing you see
is like all of the text is kind of gray

83
00:04:11.334 --> 00:04:15.867
and we've seen these things before,
we've seen these in the headers and

84
00:04:15.867 --> 00:04:18.230
footers when we put our page numbers.

85
00:04:18.230 --> 00:04:21.850
Many of those types of
fields that will update,

86
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:26.460
we also saw this when we're inserting
formulas into our tables and

87
00:04:26.460 --> 00:04:29.240
some of our previous
episodes within the show.

88
00:04:29.240 --> 00:04:34.900
So that gray backgroundy stuff, that's
an indicator to you that that's a field.

89
00:04:34.900 --> 00:04:41.742
So it's pulling from somewhere and it's
going to be able to be updated somehow.

90
00:04:41.742 --> 00:04:44.820
So that's a big one right there.

91
00:04:44.820 --> 00:04:48.250
The other thing that you can always
double check with is right clicking.

92
00:04:48.250 --> 00:04:51.890
When in doubt, right click or
try it out, when in doubt.

93
00:04:51.890 --> 00:04:54.660
Try it out, that was the saying
that Daniel came up with.

94
00:04:54.660 --> 00:04:57.800
So if you right click, and
i am over the actual field.

95
00:04:57.800 --> 00:04:59.900
It says right there, Update Link.

96
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:04.490
If I was in a regular table,
I wouldn't see things like update link.

97
00:05:04.490 --> 00:05:08.590
I would have insert row or delete rows,
or all those different items that I would

98
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:10.790
have in a normal
right-clicking of a table.

99
00:05:10.790 --> 00:05:13.510
So that's gonna be another
big indicator to me,

100
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:16.080
that this is a linked
object of some source.

101
00:05:16.080 --> 00:05:19.560
And it says, linked worksheet object.

102
00:05:19.560 --> 00:05:23.520
Cool, and I can go to things like edit
the link, open the link, convert, and

103
00:05:23.520 --> 00:05:28.380
then the links..., which is where
we get to the links dialog box.

104
00:05:28.380 --> 00:05:31.635
So that's one place
that you can get to it.

105
00:05:31.635 --> 00:05:35.302
So I think that's probably the easiest
way to see if this is a link document,

106
00:05:35.302 --> 00:05:36.470
just right click on it.

107
00:05:36.470 --> 00:05:40.800
But that links dialog box,
and the document information.

108
00:05:40.800 --> 00:05:45.430
That is a second, or another place that we
could go and find all of this information.

109
00:05:45.430 --> 00:05:49.030
So in the info section,
if you go down to the bottom,

110
00:05:49.030 --> 00:05:51.480
it's probably gonna be behind my head.

111
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:58.350
So you see right there, past open file
location, it is added link to file.

112
00:05:58.350 --> 00:06:01.614
If you see that in the document
properties, guess what,

113
00:06:01.614 --> 00:06:03.587
you've got linked information.

114
00:06:03.587 --> 00:06:06.537
I'll go ahead and click it, so
you can see this dialog box,

115
00:06:06.537 --> 00:06:09.720
as we will be coming back into
this throughout this episode.

116
00:06:09.720 --> 00:06:12.940
To do things like, hey update this link.

117
00:06:12.940 --> 00:06:16.280
And how is this not
updating when I open it?

118
00:06:16.280 --> 00:06:18.970
Cuz if you also have linked
objects in a Word document,

119
00:06:18.970 --> 00:06:22.530
you might see when you open the file up,
you'll get a warning dialog box, or

120
00:06:22.530 --> 00:06:25.210
a prompt that says, hey,
there is stuff connected to this file.

121
00:06:25.210 --> 00:06:27.450
Do you want me to go ahead and
update this?

122
00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:30.210
And usually if you want to, say yes.

123
00:06:30.210 --> 00:06:34.013
I didn't get that prompt because
I had it on a manual update.

124
00:06:34.013 --> 00:06:35.990
That means I've to force it.

125
00:06:35.990 --> 00:06:39.530
It's kinda like, kind of phones where
you can have like push notification or

126
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:43.800
have to like pull the notifications
down like, I've all my mail on pull,

127
00:06:43.800 --> 00:06:46.820
I don't have it on push because hey,
you know what, if I'm somewhere,

128
00:06:46.820 --> 00:06:49.518
I don't want my email to
be going off all day long.

129
00:06:49.518 --> 00:06:53.720
[LAUGH] So
I change it to pull within my settings.

130
00:06:53.720 --> 00:06:55.090
So it's the same thing here.

131
00:06:55.090 --> 00:06:57.810
I'm only gonna pull the information
when I want it to be pulled out.

132
00:06:57.810 --> 00:07:02.840
>> Also, I can think of this as I'm trying
to write some kind of interaction with

133
00:07:02.840 --> 00:07:04.530
a particular static setup information.

134
00:07:04.530 --> 00:07:06.260
And maybe I wanna finish that first.

135
00:07:06.260 --> 00:07:07.310
Before I do an update.

136
00:07:07.310 --> 00:07:11.340
Because maybe the behind the scenes
data is changing fairly frequently but

137
00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:12.650
I need to take a snapshot.

138
00:07:12.650 --> 00:07:15.500
Kind of persist that before
the update occurs and

139
00:07:15.500 --> 00:07:18.400
that would kind of mess up my mojo so
to speak.

140
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:20.860
If that just happened
without me being aware of it.

141
00:07:20.860 --> 00:07:22.820
>> Yeah.
That's another great example there.

142
00:07:22.820 --> 00:07:23.650
So what do you want to do?

143
00:07:23.650 --> 00:07:26.720
Do you want it automatic or
do you want to pull it down?

144
00:07:26.720 --> 00:07:30.110
For those specific reasons that
Justin was just demonstrating.

145
00:07:30.110 --> 00:07:34.020
And then we also have open source,
change source,

146

episodes.description: Daniel and Vonne present the popular mail merge process in Word 2016. In this episode, they explain the elements needed and review the process to perform a mail merge. They demonstrate a completed mail merge with a basic letter.
episodes.title: Mail Merge

episodes.description: Daniel and Vonne continue with mail merge in Word 2016. In this episode, they demonstrate how to create labels and envelopes with a mail merge. They also cover how to create a full page of the same label, print a single label on existing label paper, and print a single envelope.
episodes.title: Labels and Envelopes
